reasoning: The critique targets the toy multiplicative model in Section 2.4, which is explicitly presented as a 'toy model' illustrating a conceptual point rather than as the core argument. The essay's central argument rests on multiple pillars: (1) historical examples of moral catastrophe (Section 2.1-2.3), (2) the multiplicative model as illustration (2.4), (3) psychological biases making eutopia seem easier than it is (2.5), and most importantly (4) the systematic analysis of value functions in Section 3, which independently argues that most plausible moral views are fussy. The critique's point about independence and uniform distributions is technically correct — real factors are likely correlated and non-uniformly distributed — but this is largely 'priced in' by the authors who present it explicitly as a toy model ('as a toy model, imagine...'). The authors don't rely on the specific distributional assumptions for their conclusions; they use the model to illustrate the general principle that multiplicative structures make high-product outcomes rare. Correlations between factors could go either way (positive correlations could make good outcomes easier OR harder depending on direction), and the critique doesn't establish which direction the bias runs. The Section 3 analysis of bounded vs. unbounded views, which forms the technical backbone of the paper, is entirely unaffected by this critique. Centrality is moderate-low because the multiplicative model is illustrative rather than load-bearing; strength is low because the critique is largely anticipated by the authors' framing and doesn't establish that alternative assumptions would change the conclusion. Correctness is decent since correlations and non-uniform distributions are genuine considerations, but the critique overstates how much this 'undermines the robustness' of the broader argument.
title: Uniform factor independence assumption lacks real-world grounding
